{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3594415,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-17T00:48:39.481Z","cooked":"

Less than 24 hours ago, I posted a poll:

How did you make Bumpers in 2025? (Poll) Technical
Similar to Karthik with the prevalence of swerve, I‚Äôm rather curious as to how much the change in BUMPER rules affected this year‚Äôs robot construction. As always, feel free to post especially if you found that the questions didn‚Äôt cover your case! Ground rules for the poll part (just trying to answer questions in advance): limit to official competition, unless you only do post-season stuff this year, e.g. 2026 rookies. report most commonly used if you changed sometime during the season repor‚Ä¶

that already has at least of 400 voters just on question 1, and likely more if any skipped Q1 but answered later question(s).

I looked at the HTML/(xml) code of my original post with the polls this evening, and it is clear that there is enough information in that source code to create a table/spreadsheet with one row for each voter, and how they voted on the seven questions (four radio button questions of 3,3,5,3 and three checkbox questions of 5,4,5) that I could use to try to spot deeper patterns. Even if I were to do this manually, the results would surely change as I did the data entry, so I absolutely want to automate the ingest, and likely the further analysis.
I am perfectly capable of doing this parsing using several different tools (I‚Äôve written code with far hairier inputs), but if anyone knows of something already out there I could use, that could save me a bunch of time and effort.
On the other side, if you don‚Äôt know of such tools, is this something you would be interested in for analyzing polls in general*, and what high level tools do you have? If this is purely for myself or this poll, I would likely use MATLAB because I have a personal copy and it does all the things I need in ways I already know, and could produce data in a format I could exploit for additional analysis quite easily. My next favorite stack would be gnu tools, particularly bash, wget, gawk, and maybe sed for the parsing, which again does the things I need in ways I at least mostly know, but not as well integrated. From gnu, I would make a CSV or similar text format where I (or anyone who has any of these) could do analysis via:

  • Ingest into MATLAB
  • Ingest into a spreadsheet
  • Use more gawk tools

* Even if I write it for myself in MATLAB, I intend to post the tabulation of votes for the 2025 bumper poll as both a CSV file and in a spreadsheet format sometime this summer or early autumn after things settle down. The question is whether you want to be able to parse other CD/discourse polls (past or future) for analysis, and what tools you can access for support.

** I haven‚Äôt learned Python or Ruby or other modern open languages because I haven‚Äôt yet tackled a problem I couldn‚Äôt solve with what I already know more quickly than learning what those appeared to be. I suspect that Python will get there in the near future.

I think it‚Äôd also be interesting if you could get team number from the votes, so you can avoid double counting.

I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôd be able to entirely avoid cd sampling bias, but it‚Äôs probably better than nothing.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"updated_at":"2025-04-17T01:04:00.886Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":210,"readers_count":209,"score":47.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":499559,"topic_slug":"are-there-any-tools-already-built-to-scrape-a-cd-discourse-poll-for-analysis","display_username":"Pedro Braga","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":false},{"id":3594444,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-17T01:25:45.780Z","cooked":"

I could absolutely do this as far as identification if all posters identified as being associated with a single FRC team (some identify with two or more, sometimes many more), though it would require a second level of url retrievals to get team numbers.
The real question(s) are:

  • What to do if two or more members of the same team give different answers? Even if both identify with exactly one team, do I toss both, only keep points they agree on, or something else?
  • How do I make exceptions if one or several posters identify with more than one team? I can code this, but only once a lot of non-obvious decisions are made about such edge cases.
  • I find it hard to believe that the juice would be worth the squeeze to code around the problems I‚Äôve already stated (not to mention far worse questions in the back of my mind), but my mind is open if you think you have a viable answer.

GeeTwo:

it is clear that there is enough information in that source code to create a table/spreadsheet with one row for each vote

Is this true?

I was going to suggest that you use the JSON API to get this data but it looks to me like you‚Äôd only be able to access 25 voters per poll option from either JSON or the cooked HTML content for the post. Not sure if you can see more voters as the poll creator.

Here‚Äôs what the JSON data looks like for me:

image902√ó1647 41.4 KB

You might be able to ask a mod or admin to use the data explorer to get a full vote list for you using the discourse data explorer.

I was looking at the cooked html, and could see more than the initial 25, but not all of them on the longer ones - up to somewhere in the 40‚Äôs, but it varies question to question. I guess I‚Äôll play with this a bit to see if I actually can get the data before I bother trying to parse it.
